title: Frank Wilson-brokered sandalwood deal falls apart
text:
Back in 2017, one of the claims of Quintis' shortseller Glaucus was that Quintis' assumptions about the future price of its timber were "absurdly optimistic". Ralph Bestic

We wondered earlier this year if the sandalwood growers dragged into the implosion of Quintis had suffered enough. Alas, we hadn't known the half of it.

In late 2018, ex-Quintis chief Frank Wilson was the public face of the newly formed Sandalwood Growers Co-Op. It aimed to monetise the sandalwood Quintis' growers had spent decades cultivating. But ASIC would only approve the appointment of a responsible entity over the co-op if Wilson, the target of an ASIC civil action over an alleged lapse of disclosure at Quintis, agreed to step down as a director.

He's still closely involved on some levels though, as revealed by the spectacular unravelling late last month of a landmark sandalwood sale that had been secured by SGC.

An email sent to growers by responsible entity Huntley Asset Management on September 26 states that the principal of would-be sandalwood buyer AuSantal said he'd had "some discussions with Mr Frank Wilson of SGC over the sale and had been allowed a brief viewing of the timber stored".

Wilson rose to national prominence when he resigned as Quintis CEO shortly after an off-shore short-seller accused the company of being a Ponzi scheme. He did it to lead a takeover, which ultimately didn't eventuate. Earlier this year, the former WAFL footballer and tax lawyer lost a Supreme Court of Western Australia case over a loan. Justice Kenneth Martin described Wilson's testimony as "unreliable, implausible, self-serving and inconsistent", but his demeanour as "highly self-assured".
description: The more things change, the more they stay the same.
